snippet: A study found that the forces underlying the jump in military suicides were similar to those in the civilian world: mental illness, substance abuse, and financial and relationship problems.
abstract: Study by military medical researchers concludes that deployments to war zones and exposure to combat are not major factors in sharp rise in military suicides from 2001 to 2008; study, published online by Journal of the American Medical Association, finds that underlying forces are similar to those in civilian world, including mental illness, substance abuse, and financial and relationship problems.
lead_paragraph: A study found that the forces underlying the jump in military suicides were similar to those in the civilian world: mental illness, substance abuse, and financial and relationship problems.

headline.main: Deployment Factors Are Not Related to Rise in Military Suicides, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: Deployment Factors Are Not Related to Rise in Military Suicides, Study Finds
